text: {{Infobox writer | name = Bernard Malamud | image = Bernard Malamud portrait.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = Brooklyn, New York, United States | death_date = | death_place = Manhattan, New York, United States | occupation = Author, teacher | nationality = American | period = 1940–1985 | genre = Novel, short story | subject = | movement = | notableworks = The Natural, The Fixer | signature = | website = }}Bernard Malamud (April 26, 1914 – March 18, 1986) was an American novelist and short story writer. He was one of the best known American Jewish authors of the 20th century. His baseball novel, The Natural, was made into a 1984 movie. His 1966 novel The Fixer (also filmed), about antisemitism in the Russian Empire, won both the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize. Malamud died in Manhattan on March 18, 1986 from a heart attack, at the age of 71. ==References== Category:1914 births Category:1986 deaths Category:American novelists Category:Writers from New York City Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction Category:Pulitzer Prize winners Category:O.
